intro: Malvastrum dimorphum, commonly known as the two-form mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in summer. Its leaves are ovate with serrated edges, and it often grows in dry, rocky soils. Malvastrum dimorphum is typically found in disturbed areas and can thrive in full sun.
